comments.commentBody: Not true. Reclining makes it impossible to use your tray table for food or a laptop, even if you recline as well.
a tape measure
The airlines are grossly negligent in even allowing anyone to recline.

I wasn't aware of the knee defender even being on the market. That said, it is really a tool to help you to be extremely rude.

Since when is it up to the person who is sitting behind you, to decide whether or not you are going to recline your seat.

In addition, the idea of having to pay someone to have them not recline their seat is ridiculous.

When you buy an airplane ticket, you are aware of the fact that the seats recline. It is a fact that is beyond your control. If you cannot except this fact, then find an alternative method of transportation. Period.

To be so self righteous as to assume that you have control over whether or not the person in the seat in front of you is going to recline the seat is more proof of the sad trend that people in the world are following.

I'm tall (6'-3") and I've never said anything about a reclining seat in front of me, even though it means my knees have to intrude on those seated next to me and I am quite uncomfortable. I simply don't fit if someone reclines their seat. If I'm traveling personally, these days I usually pay for more legroom. However, I also travel for business and they would look at me like I was insane if I asked for an upgrade.

I think a better question is why do you have to recline? That extra two inches in the setback is going make such a difference in your comfort and life?! Who would notice? I never recline my seat and on most flights I've been on in the past year, no one has. I think if you want to recline, you should pay for that privilege. You've completely missed the argument: most people don't care if their seats recline. Airline seats should be fixed unless you pay to recline. And think for the airline savings: the flight attendants would not have to remind people to put their seats in the upright position for takeoff/landing. We'll be flying cross-country for 50 bucks.

I have a pinched nerve in my neck and shoulder that I have been trying to get resolved for over 30 years. When someone fully reclines, it forces my back and therefore my neck in a position that compresses the nerve and causes extreme pain. I am with Wendi, they should have coach seats that don't recline and those that do. Let the passengers choose rather than suffer.

I have to travel for work and have family in other areas of the country and have to fly, so driving is not an option
People like Ms. Hoyn are so beautiful for showing the world how ugly humans can be.
Why don't we let the airlines forget about seats altogether and place us into the cargo hold. Sorry, we are paying to fly and not to be crushed while doing so.
Sounds to me like the prizefighter is pretty entitled.

There is nothing wrong with preventing others from reclining into your personal space.

Even if you have an expectation of reclining because you paid for a reclining seat, you also should have an expectation that the degree to which you recline cannot press on the knees of the person behind you. In some cases, such as when the knees of the person behind you are already touching your seatback in the fully upright position, this means that you will not be able to recline at all without damaging that person's knees. The people who insist on reclining anyway are probably the same ones who grabbed all the blocks in kindergarten.

So someone has invented a device that allows you to be the only one in the economy cabin who doesn't have to allow the person in front to put their seat back? Well, as George Orwell observed, some pigs are just more equal than others. He was probably the kid who grabbed all the blocks in kindergarten, too.

I had just spent 12 days in a hospital in a ski town with a broken tibia. I was taken from the hospital in wheel chair to the airport to fly back to NY. It was a small plane and the flight to Denver took 25 minutes. I was still dazed from my hospital stay when the lady in front of me, traveling with her small daughter, on the seat next to her, reclined her seat. I was on the last seat, single row, because the wheelchair could not go down the aisle. I called the stewardess and asked if there was another seat where I could move to. There wasn't. Very politely the stewardess asked the passenger if she could bring her seat back up or switch places with her daughter who didn't want her seat to recline. The lady in front said flatly: "No, I won't." I still could not bend my knee properly and the orthopedic boot I was wearing was bulky. It was torture for 20 minutes. There was nothing I could do, but I was more concerned about the example the "lady" in front of me was giving to her little daughter, as I had two young sons myself. This was a very long time ago, but I never forgot it.

What about the inconvenience and pain to the back of the person in front of you who cannot recline?  Is her pain less important than the pain of your knees?  Are you rights more important than the rights of the person in front of you?
Believe me, the pain of being reclined on is MUCH greater than the pain of not being able to recline.  Reclining is rude.
Perhaps for you. The seats are designed to recline. You buy your seat knowing that it can recline and the person in front of you may recline. That is the boundaries of the space you've purchased.

Airlines discriminate against tall people. A six foot tall man is in the 80th percentile of the US population. So approximately 20% of American adult males experience crunched legs. If airlines had the same constraints for body weight, men over 180 pounds would have to hold in their gut. Imagine how that would go over.

Squished legs can have serious consequences for tall people - besides basic comfort, being unable to move your legs for long periods of time can increase the chances of blood clots and numbness.

Only about 10% of the US is over 6’ tall. There is not enough backlash, so airlines see it is a money making opportunity. It is a corrupt one. Height is a genetic quality, charging a subset of the population for their basic comfort is as egregious as up-charging for another genetic characteristic such as race.

Up to 4” more legroom! Only $69! Delta always offers me. Unfortunately, a seat in ‘premium economy’ still doesn’t have enough leg room when the seat in front is fully reclined. My only choice then is Business or First Class. My $789 per inch of my extra height doesn’t get me far: business class from LA to London starts at $3500 more than coach, I’m still in the hole.

I won’t buy the knee defender this time around, but I’ll feel no need to hold back my squeal in pain next time a Mr Barro reclines his seat back into my knees. Even if he won’t put his seat in it’s full upright position, maybe he’ll turn around long enough to apologize for the inconvenience.

Some Asian airlines have tried this. The seat is in a hard shell that sort of drops down and goes forward, so if you decided to fully recline, you would end up very close to the floor with a good bit of you lying under the seat in front of you. It sounds like a terrific idea to me, but I believe I have heard this has not been that popular on the airlines that use them and at least one airline has reportedly decided to take them out.

Is being unusually tall a disability?  No.  Therefore, it is not covered by the ADA.  Being morbidly obese may be considered a disability.  So here's the irony of your proposal: you have no choice in being tall yet you cannot be accommodated with more legroom because you are not disabled.  Many if not most obese people do have at least some choice in their obesity yet they would be accommodated with wider seats.  Sound fair to you?

Regardless of the thoughts of many commenters here, when you buy a seat, that does *not* give you the right to recline a seat into someone's space, to the point where they are extremely uncomfortable, or even in pain.. One does not buy the right to invade the space of and to be rude to others!

Sadly, the *real* problem is the airline - which proposes to save money by setting one passenger and their rights against another. The customers should not be set up to have conflict against one another. How about designing s cabin such that there is room for everyone.

Between the airlines chiseling passengers, and the rude passengers who believe they have rights to be nasty because they "paid for it," the whole thing just goes to show that we should all stop flying. Maybe we will be fortunate enough to all develop some manners - or put a greedy airline or two out of business. We can but hope...

"More bombing means more death?"

I'm not so sure about that in this case. ISIS may or may not be a direct threat to the mainland US, but they certainly have the capacity to overrun major parts of Iraq and Syria, murdering civilians along the way for offending Allah, as well as POWs. Even Al Qaeda can't stomach ISIS, because they are too brutal and inhumane.

I would argue that bombing Germany and Japan led to "less violence and less death"--as a classic example of "when" bombing ends further bloodshed. I agree, the death and violence is aweful. But, I fear that not striking ISIS and their ideologically driven psychopathic violence would have even more catastrophic consequences...
No unilateral action by the US makes sense. ISIS is dangerous. Assad is dangerous. More bombing means more death. When has bombing led to less violence and less death?

Exactly. I'm a progressive who favors much tighter restrictions on guns but also finds the amount of pearl clutching on this topic frustrating. It's an Olympic sport for heaven's sake. No, 9 year olds should not be firing Uzi's. But target practice with .22's at a shooting range is perfectly appropriate. I personally have no interest in shooting but was happy to congratulate my son on the award he won at the camp rifle range nonetheless.

There should be sections of the plane where reclining is acceptable and sections where the sits don't recline.  People can then choose when selecting a seat whether or not they want to have the right to recline.  I have experienced it from both sides.  At times when I fly across the country or to a foreign country I need to get work done on my computer.  If the person in front of me reclines, I can't work and thus am irritated. On the other hand, at times I really want to recline my seat and sleep; but have to worry about bothering the person in back of me.  If I could preselect whether or not to sit in a reclining section that would be great.

What annoys me the most and a majority of people do it - They don't check behind the seat to see what the person behind them is doing or they don't slowly recline the seat back to give the person behind them fair warning! No the simply whack the sit back  - I have been hit in the head a few times when i have reaching down to get something and the person has just thrusted the seat backwards but also what annoys me is that the airline tells you when it is time to eat put your seats back to its original position and a lot of the times no one does it and the flighties don't enforce the rules!
Come on Luke, tell me which airline you are working for.
"One has to think of this in terms of economics." No, one does not, that's simply a convenient excuse to avoid any thought about manners.

You write: "If the seat reclines, then that means you get to recline it all the way."

No, it absolutely doesn't mean that! My right to my space sitting behind you is no less than your right to the reclining space behind you that you claim. If your seat reclines, that means that you get to recline your seat... until it makes contact with my kneecaps, and no further. I'm tall enough that a typical seats can't recline 100% prior to hitting my knees, and I have literally had people in front of me attempt to punish me for the length of my legs by sitting far forward, pushing their recline button, and then throwing their whole body weight backwards - and repeating this every five minutes during an 8-hour flight. Are they just exercising their "right" to their purchased space? What about my purchased space? The space my body occupies has not been purchased by anyone else on the plane, period.

While alcohol (really ethanol) can be toxic in excess, it is also a normal intermediate product of human metabolism. It is misleading at best to call it an actual poison as you do. (And, no, I am not trying to rationalize a drinking habit as I only very rarely drink and never very much.)

I do completely agree with the comment that Bitman is not an expert in anything and only a real fool would lie to his doctor.

I don't think anyone is defending "it"...they are concerned that "this" will be used as another excuse to disarm law abiding citizens. The only person who can be said to shoulder the responsibility for this accident is dead. Its unfortunate and a high price to pay, but it was paid by the one who SHOULD pay...the guy who put the gun in her hand.

I hope the girl can come to grips with this tragedy...my thoughts are with her.

This type of accident may be extremely rare, but a human being lost his life.  And the accident was totally preventable if reasonable common sense were consulted.  No, this accident crosses the line into the territory of negligence with fatal consequences.

I am not a gun owner and I think the gun culture in our country is out of control. However, I don't think it's fair to say that responsible gun ownership is an oxymoron.

However, I do think it's time that we impose some responsibilities to go along with the rights of gun ownership. I think that if you own a gun and someone in your household uses it to kill someone, you should be subject to criminal penalties. I'm thinking about parents whose kids take their guns and use them to shoot up their school. You are making a choice to own something that can be used to kill people, and if you enable murder in that way, you should have some responsibility for the outcome.

As "Concerned Citizen" points out, we don't ban automobiles because people are killed by the on a regular basis. We do however, require you to be 16 to be able to drive, require licenses that have to be renewed on a regular basis, and impose criminal penalties when automobiles are used in a negligent fashion. If I hit someone because I'm driving 100 miles and hour and lose control of my car, I'm guessing I would be facing criminal charges of some sort.

I really don't understand why it shouldn't be the same with guns.
CC so we should get rdid of the ban on drunk driving?
Responsible gun ownership is an oxymoron. If you're responsible, you don't own guns. If you do own them, you're a deadly accident waiting to happen.

Without Louis XVI's spending on 'foreign wars,' the American Revolution would likely have been suppressed. Cancel the American Revolution and - perhaps - a cliquish combination of aristocracy, clergy and landowners avert the French Revolution and, subsequently, Napoleon's rise in defense of it.

Sooner or later kings and the dictators fail in their warrior stylings and imperious control. Best to replace them with Jeffersonian democracy, I say -- meaning an informed, conscientious vote by the general public -- than to seat new kings and oligarchs. Revolutionary America learned that lesson; Revolutionary France did not.

November's coming. Suppress the oligarchs. Get out the vote.
